content:
I see what the problem is.
The validators are NOTHING like the tests. The rule is that they should be different, but comparable. The values you used in the validators are with 5-6 digits. I started with a minimum of 99999, which was then reduced every time I encountered a lower value, to find the smallest available slice after each of Maks's choices. When I saw I had 100%, and it was a "SHORTEST" mode Clash, I tried 9999, and then 999, as the original value, and it worked fine each time.
This worked for all of the tests and only one of the validators.
Regardless, it is plain to see that the tests are miles off from the validators. They are a completely different set of problems.

Hi there.
Interesting problem, but I had 100% on all tests, and 16% on submission.
I don't know what is wrong, but that's definitely not a good sign.
Sorry, guys! I added an extra part to the problem statement to address the ambiguity.
Hi, you should also write on the condition that priority is given to Maks.

Let's study this case :
5 3
4
2
100
1
100
    The lowest value is 1 , that might be the slice of Pizza Lina wants to take. But for Maks to take the biggest area of pizza he has to take the values 100 , 1 , 100 ; ' 1 ' is common for both Lina and Maks . How shall we deal with this case , sould Lina take the slice of 2 units or Maks must take the 4 , 2 ,100 as the only contiguous alternative without 1 ?
Actually in this case  Maks could (and should) take 4, 2, 100, then Lina takes 1, finally Maks takes 100.

Aaah, sorry, I misunderstood the statement, and thought they are eating after each other until they eat everything. 

If they are eating only 1 and K slices in total, leave everything else, then DinoFromChrome's question remains. Which is more important: to have the lowest possible value for Lina, or to have the highest value for Maks.

(Btw. there is no such thing as "most optimal" solution. The optimal solution is the best possible one, so there cannot be a better one :) )

The output is 2 201 because Maks will take the two 100 slices. This was addressed in the last test case "The Pizza Is Aggressive" already, but I understand that the reasoning was missing. The reasoning has been added to the problem statement.
